newsitem.title: USA: AOL reports Q3 profit, marketing costs drop.
newsitem.headline: AOL reports Q3 profit, marketing costs drop.

text.p: America Online Inc said it reported a profit in its third quarter of $2.6 million, or $0.02 a share, primarily due to lower marketing expenses in its first full quarter since it started flat rate pricing.
Wall Street had been expecting AOL to report a loss, with the First Call consensus estimate of a loss of $0.07 a share.

AOL said that as it had planned, it held its membership relatively flat at about 8 million subscribers, while it worked to improve access for existing members. When it launched its flat-rate pricing in December, a surge in demand for its service led to network access problems for its members.
AOL's revenues climbed to a record $456.2 million, up 46 percent from total revenues of a year-ago of $312.3 million.

AOL also said that its other, non-subscription revenues grew to $74.7 million. Within other revenues, advertising and electronic commerce revenues were $60.7 million in the third quarter, up 37 percent from the December quarter.

The company also said that as expected, member cancellation increased in January, due to the change to flat-rate pricing and because of access issues. But the world's largest online service also said that its member retention improved steadily as the quarter progressed.
AOL said that both trial member conversions and retention rates for April hit their highest levels in the past year.
AOL said that it recently resumed marketing on a limited basis and plans to continue carefully balancing demand for the service with its ability to keep improving access.
When its members started experiencing major problems in January in accessing the system, AOL announced a $350 million system expansion program.
"As promised, we have worked around the clock to serve our existing members first and our top priority was, and still is, improving access," said AOL Chairman and CEO Steve Case.
"At the same time, we have achieved profitability a bit ahead of schedule," Case continued in a statement.
AOL also said that its cash position improved to $197.8 million, from $130.2 million in the December quarter.

As of March 31, AOL had $211.2 million in deferred revenues, up from $95.4 million in the December quarter, primarily reflecting advance subscription payments and its marketing agreement with Tel-Save Holdings Inc. A year ago, AOL reported $33.5 million in deferred revenue.
AOL said that as part of its system expansion program, it has installed more than 75,000 new modems in its AOLNet network.

AOL said that during the quarter, it signed up 27 new advertisers, despite it being a seasonally slow period for advertising. AOL said it now has over 180 advertising clients, including companies such as Barnes & Noble Inc, American Greetings and TRW Inc.
